week.conteudo: As I mentioned in my bio, I started my career in a telemarketing job. After almost a year, I got a call from my old boss who asked me, 'Do you like IT?'. That moment sparked my transition into technology.
I'm always looking to improve, as you may have seen, I always like to learn and discover new things, so I set up this project where I will talk about everything I learned during a week.

Recently, I developed a landing page in JavaScript to refresh my skills. The project helps a local solar energy company generate leads. The site explains the benefits of solar energy, average savings, and invites users to fill out a contact form.

Key Features:
- Clean, modern design with colorful visual identity
- Educational sections explaining how solar power works
- Accordion-style FAQs to improve user experience
- Highlighted savings and benefits of adopting solar energy
- Functional contact form to collect name, email, and phone number
- Fully responsive layout for mobile and desktop
- Hosted with GitHub Pages

View the live site:
https://eduardo-bidoja.github.io/octopus-solar
GitHub repo:
https://github.com/Eduardo-bidoja/octopus-solar

Yesterday, Monday the 7th, Michel challenged me and I only had 15 minutes to do a small project. I'll summarize a little about what it was. I had to create an application that would calculate payment installments according to some specific rules. Well, I had 15 minutes to do it, but I had all the time I needed to think about how to do it. I thought: (This guy is crazy. This is impossible.) After almost 7 hours, I stopped and analyzed what he told me during our conversation, that it doesn't matter how you do it, as long as you show that you know what you're doing and how you're doing it. I decided to use Gemini because I already know the platform and how to use it. I finally got it. Hahaha. After almost 7 hours thinking about how to do it, I got it in less than 10 minutes. Here is the final project of the challenge, but I still think he's a little crazy. Hahaha, but I understood his proposal. What he wanted to convey was that it doesn't matter how you get there, as long as you know what you're doing and how you're doing it. This is the most important thing.
